{{EngvarB|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} The '''Certificate in Legal Practice''' ('''CLP''') is a 9-month long post-graduate course and examination taken by foreign [[Bachelor of Laws|law]] graduates and graduates of Bachelor of Jurisprudence (Hons)/B.Juris (Hons) from [[University of Malaya]]<ref>http://www.um.edu.my/mainpage.php?module=Maklumat&kategori=82&id=545&papar=1</ref> and Bachelor of Legal Studies (Hons)/BLS (Hons) from [[Universiti Teknologi MARA]],<ref>http://www.law.uitm.edu.my/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=74:lw213-b-hons-of-legal-studies&catid=50:degree&Itemid=63 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005200937/http://www.law.uitm.edu.my/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=74%3Alw213-b-hons-of-legal-studies&catid=50%3Adegree&Itemid=63 |date=5 October 2011 }}</ref> to become a qualified [[lawyer]] in [[Malaysia]].<ref>http://www.malaysianbar.org.my/c.l.p.html</ref><ref>http://www.lpqb.org.my/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=132&Itemid=77</ref>
The examination is conducted by the Legal Profession Qualifying Board of Malaysia and is governed by the Legal Profession Act 1976. The Board allows degree holders from shortlisted universities in the [[United Kingdom]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]] to sit for the examination.<ref>"A Guideline and the Application Form to sit for the Examination for the Certificate of Legal Practice", ''Legal Profession Qualifying Board, Malaysia''</ref> The Board also allows graduates from a shortlisted universities to be exempted from the this examination.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lpqb.org.my/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=47&Itemid=61|title=About Us|last=Administrator|website=www.lpqb.org.my|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>Multimedia University in Melaka is the 1st private university in Malaysia obtaining exemption of CLP exam for its law graduates.
Like all law graduates, CLP graduates must proceed to read in chambers of a pupil master who has been in active practice in Malaysia for a total period of not less than 7 years. After completing nine (9) months of pupillage, the student may finally be [[call to the bar|called]] to the [[Malaysian Bar|bar]] and become a qualified lawyer.
==History== The Certificate in Legal Practice was originally designed in 1984 only as a temporary stop-gap measure to assist those Malaysians who were not able to sit for the English Bar Finals Examinations.<ref>http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/6/focus/8011437&sec=focus{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It was then a solution to those who can't apply to be a Barrister but ended up as another recognised legal qualification to be an advocate and solicitor in Malaysia.
==The Examination== Examinations are normally held around July each year. Every student is required to sit for five subject papers, namely, General Paper, Professional Practice, Evidence, Criminal Procedure, and Civil Procedure. The student must pass all papers to obtain the certificate. If a student fails one paper he or she may be given a conditional pass and be allowed to resit that subject two more times. However, if a student failed in two or more papers, he must sit for the whole examination again to obtain the certificate. Each student is allowed to sit for the examination four times.
The Legal Profession Qualifying Board only sets the examination and does not provide classes to prepare the candidate for the examination. Classes were initially conducted by the Faculty of Law, [[University of Malaya]] and later [[UiTM Malaysia Law School|Faculty of Law, Universiti Teknologi MARA]] but the task was subsequently delegated to private colleges only. Three of the major institutions that offer tuition for the CLP in Kuala Lumpur are Brickfields Asia College [http://www.bac.edu.my/], Advance Tertiary College (formerly Kemayan ATC), and HELP University. ATC also offers the course in its Penang Campus.
==Criticism and Controversies== The examination is extremely rigorous in that it has a very low passing rate of between 10% to 20% each year. This is due to the extremely high standard imposed by the CLP Board to ensure that only the best candidates go on to qualify and practice as lawyers.
The CLP board has pointed out, among other things, in an article published in The Star on 24 September 2008 as well as in its CLP Subject Guide 2008 issued to candidates, that “The examination is not a test of memory function by the candidates. It is the mediocre candidates who resort to regurgitation of information memorized by them”, thereby leading to the low pass rates annually.<ref>http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/9/24/nation/2086475&sec=nation{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Professional Practice paper, for example, covers of Land Law, Probate and Administration of Estates, Bankruptcy and Winding Up, Ethics of the Legal Profession, and Advocacy. Any person familiar with legal education would understand that Land Law is among the bulkiest subject.
Students were denied access to the many relevant Statutes (Acts of Parliaments) during the exams, such as the Bankruptcy Act 1967, Companies Act 1965, Winding Up Rules 1997, Probate and Administration Act 1959, Legal Profession Act 1976, Legal Profession (Practice & Etiquette) Rules 1978, Legal Profession (Publicity) Rules, and many more.
In 2007, the then CLP Director, Khalid Yusoff, was jailed three months for forgery and cheating in the July 2001 CLP examination “master list”.<ref>http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2007/8/1/nation/18461427&sec=nation{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In May 2010, he was freed by the Court of Appeal.<ref>http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2010/5/28/courts/6353135&sec=courts{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

page.title: Charles I Insulted by Cromwell's Soldiers

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Charles I Insulted by Cromwell's Soldiers.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = Charles I Insulted by Cromwell's Soldiers <small>(detail)</small> | alt = Charles I Insulted by Cromwell's Soldiers (partial detail) | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Hippolyte Delaroche|Delaroche]] | year = {{Start date|1836}} <!--remove date template if before 1583 CE --> | medium = [[Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | height_imperial = 120 | width_imperial = 156 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = London | museum = [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]] }} '''''Charles I Insulted by Cromwell's Soldiers''''' is an [[oil painting]] by the French artist [[Hippolyte Delaroche]], depicting [[Charles I of England]] taunted by the victorious soldiers of [[Oliver Cromwell]] after the [[Second English Civil War]], prior to his execution in 1649. Completed in 1836, it is thought to be one of Delaroche's greatest masterpieces. It was displayed as part of the [[Orleans Collection#Bridgewater collection|Bridgewater Collection]] in London, although it was latterly thought to have been lost when, during [[The Blitz]] of 1941, a German bomb struck close to [[Bridgewater House, Westminster|Bridgewater House]], causing shrapnel damage to the canvas in the ensuing explosion. In 2009 it was rediscovered in Scotland in an unexpectedly good condition, having been rolled up and stored after the war, but recorded in the intervening years as badly damaged or destroyed. After a partial restoration it went on display in the [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]] in London, in an exhibition re-appraising Delaroche's work. After the exhibition, it is to be fully restored.
==Subject== [[File:DelarocheCromwell.jpg|thumb|right|In ''Cromwell and Charles I'' painted in 1831, Delaroche also depicts Charles I, with Cromwell standing over his dead body]] ''Charles I Insulted'' features Charles I, the King of England, who had by 1648 lost the Second English Civil War fought against Oliver Cromwell's New Model Army, after the [[Battle of Preston (1648)|Battle of Preston]]. By January 1649, he was being put on trial for treason, and on 30 January, he was [[Decapitation|beheaded]].
The painting depicts Charles in the days before his execution, being bullied and taunted by Cromwell's defiant troops, one of whom is blowing [[Pipe smoking|pipe smoke]] in his face.<ref name=BBC24Nov2009ReturningAfter70Years/><ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/> The deposed king remains calm, holding a book which he appears to have been reading.
==Ownership== [[Hippolyte Delaroche|Delaroche]]'s ''Charles I Insulted'' was commissioned by [[Francis Egerton, 1st Earl of Ellesmere]],<ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/> who was known as Lord Francis Leveson-Gower until 1833 when, following the death of his father, he was created the first [[Earl of Ellesmere]], inheriting [[Bridgewater House, Westminster|Bridgewater House]] in London from his bachelor great uncle, [[Francis Egerton, 3rd Duke of Bridgewater]].<ref name=Telegraph22Sep2000SutherlandObituary/> The family line of the Earls of Ellesmere became the Dukes of Sutherland when, in 1963, [[John Egerton, 6th Duke of Sutherland|John Egerton, 5th Earl of Ellesmere]], succeeded to the title of duke of Sutherland on the death of the 5th Duke of Sutherland with no male heir in the elder line.<ref name=Telegraph22Sep2000SutherlandObituary/> As of its rediscovery in 2009, the painting remained privately owned by the present Duke, [[Francis Egerton, 7th Duke of Sutherland]].<ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/> The 7th Duke was the 6th Duke's cousin and heir to the Dukedom, since the 6th Duke had no children himself.<ref name=Telegraph22Sep2000SutherlandObituary/>
==History==
===1836 to 2009=== ''Charles I Insulted'' is a large piece, painted on a canvas measuring {{convert|13|ft|m}} by {{convert|10|ft|m}}.,<ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/> also described as being nearly three metres square.<ref name=Guardian23Feb2010Strike/> It was completed in 1836.<ref name=BBC24Nov2009ReturningAfter70Years/> It was first displayed at the [[Salon (Paris)|Paris Salon]] of 1837,<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/> and in 1838 at the [[British Institution]] in London. The painting was then hung for decades as part of the semi-public [[Orleans Collection#Bridgewater collection|Bridgewater Collection]] in Bridgewater House in London.<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/>
The painting suffered serious damage during a Second World War German bombing raid on London. Unlike other collections, the Bridgewater artworks had not been stored underground before the war, due to the 5th Earl having been captured at [[Dunkirk evacuation|Dunkirk]] in 1940.<ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/> On 11 May 1941, during the last night and most deadly raid of what became known as [[The Blitz]], one bomb landed on the street outside Bridgewater House, leaving a {{convert|3|m|ft}} deep [[bomb crater]]. Hanging in the dining room at the time, the painting suffered extensive [[Shrapnel shell|shrapnel]] damage.<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/> At least four paintings in the collection were totally destroyed in the raid, while others less damaged were eventually restored.<ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/> ''Charles I Insulted'' was demounted, and rolled up, having been given a rudimentary repair using paper to hold together the largest tears.<ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/> After the war, it was transported to [[Mertoun House]] in [[St. Boswells]], [[Scottish Borders]], the family's Scottish home, for storage.<ref name=BBC24Nov2009ReturningAfter70Years/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Telegraph22Sep2000SutherlandObituary/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/><ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/>
While stored safe and dry in Mertoun, over the next 68 years the existence of the painting was gradually forgotten about by its owners, and presumed by the art world to be lost as irreparably damaged in the raid.<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/> In subsequent catalogues of Delaroche's work, it had been listed as either 'badly damaged' or sometimes 'destroyed'.<ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/>
===2009 onwards=== The painting was rediscovered in the summer of 2009 by National Gallery curators, after they made enquiries about the painting as they prepared a Delaroche exhibition.<ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/><ref name=Mail26Nov2009Found/> The 2010 exhibition was to be the first major show on Delaroche to be held in Britain, aiming to re-assess the works of Delaroche, who fell out of fashion during the early 20th century, and featuring his most famous work from the National Gallery collection, ''[[The Execution of Lady Jane Grey]]'' (1833), which was also a rediscovered work: it had been thought lost when the Tate Gallery was [[1928 Thames flood|flooded in 1928]], and found rolled up in 1973.<ref name=BBC24Nov2009ReturningAfter70Years/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/>
On 7 June 2009 at Mertoun, it was unrolled for the first time since being moved to Scotland.<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/> To the surprise of those present, the painting was largely intact, having "lost none of its intensity".<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/> The explosion damage consisted of around 200 individual tears in the canvas, which still contained plaster fragments and dust from the blast.<ref name=BBC24Nov2009ReturningAfter70Years/><ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Times13Feb2010StarPariah/>
After moving the painting to London, it was restored sufficiently to be able to be displayed in the exhibition, albeit with the shrapnel scars still visible, and "somewhat yellowed by a layer of discoloured varnish".<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/><ref name=Times13Feb2010StarPariah/> Because the canvas had been rolled up for nearly 70 years, it had to be weighed down flat for six weeks.<ref name=Guardian23Feb2010Strike/> The tears were then stitched together, and the canvas lined.<ref name=Guardian23Feb2010Strike/>
The painting's first ever public display since rediscovery was as part of the exhibition ''Painting History: Delaroche and Lady Jane Grey'', running from 24 February to 24 May 2010.<ref name=BBC24Nov2009ReturningAfter70Years/><ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/><ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/> It went on display on 23 February in a separate room in the museum's free admission area, with the main part of the exhibition held in the adjacent [[Sainsbury Wing]] of the gallery.<ref name=Reuters23Feb2010WorkOnShow/> The painting is to be fully restored after the London exhibition whereupon work would start to remove the discoloured varnish and retouch the damaged areas.<ref name=Guardian23Feb2010Strike/><ref name=Reuters23Feb2010WorkOnShow/>
==Reception== According to the London National Gallery, it is "one of the great paintings on themes of English history for which Delaroche had become renowned", in which Delaroche was "able to imply striking parallels between the poignant fate of Charles and the recent course of French history".<ref name=NatGallAMasterpieceRecoveredCharlesIInsulted/> According to the gallery director [[Nicholas Penny]], the rediscovery was "huge" and its redisplay would be an historic moment, describing it as "an extraordinarily powerful work", "one of the great French paintings" and by "one of the greatest painters" of the 19th century.<ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/><ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/> According to Penny, Delaroche, a Frenchman, was a notable painter of [[Tudor dynasty|Tudor]] and [[House of Stuart|Stuart]] history, as a method of "exploring the violence and vicissitudes of the [[French Revolution]]" without actually portraying the events themselves, which were regarded as too recent to paint.<ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/>
According to the National Gallery's exhibition curator Christopher Riopelle, both ''Charles I Insulted'' and Delaroche's other painting, ''[[Marie-Antoinette]] Before the Tribunal'', painted fifteen years later in 1851, "suggest episodes of the [[suffering of Christ]]".<ref name=Reuters23Feb2010WorkOnShow/> Riopelle added that Delaroche's "obsession with English royalist history" was "classic displacement of what you want to talk about but can't, because it's still so raw and recent", particularly referring to [[Execution of Louis XVI|the execution]] of [[Louis XVI of France]] in January 1793, and nine months later of his Queen [[Marie Antoinette]].<ref name=Guardian23Feb2010Strike/>
[[Charlotte Higgins]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' described it as "one of Delaroche's masterpieces", which "owes a debt" to [[Anthony van Dyck]]'s famous painting of Charles I.<ref name=Guardian24Nov2009FearedLost/> Higgins also said that it "clearly references the popular artistic subject of the [[mocking of Christ]] by his guards".<ref name=Guardian23Feb2010Strike/> According to Arifa Akbar of ''[[The Independent]]'', "Delaroche's monumental painting featuring Charles I as a Christ-like figure" is regarded as "one of Delaroche's most powerful pieces", commissioned at the "height of his fame".<ref name=Independent24Nov2009Blitzed/>
[[David Horspool]] of ''[[The Times]]'', reflecting on the fate of Delaroche's ''Execution of Lady Jane Grey'' which was relegated to a basement, in which it was later flood damaged, due to Delaroche's falling fame, said "there seems no chance that [''Charles I Insulted''] will be rolled up and put away. Delaroche's days as the forgotten master seem to be over", predicting the rediscovered piece would be perhaps "the most exciting exhibit to go on display" in the 2010 National Gallery exhibition.<ref name=Times13Feb2010StarPariah/>

'''Computer-assisted legal research''' ('''CALR''')<ref>[http://www.aallnet.org/products/pub_llj_v97n02/2005-16.pdf Assessing the Influence of Computer-Assisted Legal Research: A Study of California Supreme Court Opinions]</ref> or '''computer-based legal research''' is a mode of [[legal research]] that uses databases of court opinions, statutes, court documents, and secondary material. Electronic databases make large bodies of case law easily available. Databases also have additional benefits, such as [[Boolean algebra#Boolean operations|Boolean searches]], evaluating case authority, organizing cases by topic, and providing links to cited material. Databases are available through paid subscription or for free.<ref>Kate Marquess, Caught in the Web: Survey Reveals Increasing Use of Internet in Law Practices, but Lawyers Are Making Transition Slowly, A.B.A. J., Dec. 2000, at 76.</ref>
Subscription-based services include [[Westlaw]], [[LexisNexis]], [[JustCite]], [[HeinOnline]], [[Bloomberg Law]], [[VLex]] and [[LexEur]]. As of 2015 the commercial market grossed $8 billion.<ref name=NYT102815>{{cite news|author1=Erik Eckholm|title=Harvard Law Library Readies Trove of Decisions for Digital Age|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/29/us/harvard-law-library-sacrifices-a-trove-for-the-sake-of-a-free-database.html|accessdate=October 29, 2015 |work=The New York Times|date=October 28, 2015|quote=a commercial market surpassing $8 billion}}</ref> Free services include [[OpenJurist]], [[Google Scholar]], [[AltLaw]], [[Ravel Law]],<ref name=NYT102815/> [[WIPO Lex]], [[Law Delta]] and the databases of the [[Free Access to Law Movement]].
==Purposes== Computer-assisted legal research is undertaken by a variety of actors. It is taught as a topic on many [[law degree]]s<ref>James Holland and Jullian Webb, ''Learning Legal Rules'' (7th edn., Oxford University Press, 2010)</ref> and is used extensively by undergraduate and postgraduate law students in meeting the work requirements of their degree courses. Professors of Law rely on the digitisation of primary and secondary sources of law when conducting their research and writing the material that they submit for publication. Professional lawyers rely on computer-assisted legal research in order to properly understand the status of the law and so to act effectively in the best interest of their client. They may also consult the text of case judgements and statutes specifically, as well as wider academic comment, in order to form the basis of (or response to) an appeal.
The availability of legal information online differs by type, jurisdiction and subject matter. The types of information available include:<ref>See e.g. http://legalresearch.westlaw.co.uk/; http://www.lexisnexis.co.uk/en-uk/home.page; http://www.legislation.gov.uk; https://www.jstor.org</ref>
# Texts of statutes, statutory instruments, civil codes, etc. # Explanatory notes and government publications relating to statutes and their operation # Texts of governing documents such as constitutions and treaties # Case judgements # Journals on legal matters or legal theory # Dictionaries and legal encyclopaediæ # Legal texts and materials in the form of e-books # Current affairs and market information # Educational information on the law and its operation
==Before the Internet==
Prior to the advent and popularisation of the World Wide Web, access to digital legal information was largely through the use of CD-ROMs, designed and sold by commercial organisations.<ref name="India 2015">The "free access to law movement" in India: supporting legal education, research and practice Priya Rai and Akash Singh (2015) Legal Information Management 178</ref> Dial-up services were also available from the 1970s.<ref>Archived February 28, 2008, at the Wayback Machine</ref> As the use of the Internet spread in the early 1990s, companies such as LexisNexis and Westlaw incorporated Internet connectivity into their software packages. Browser-based legal information started to be published by Legal Information Institutes from 1992.<ref name="law.cornell.edu">LII/Legal Information Institute, Cornell University https://www.law.cornell.edu/</ref>
==Publicly available information== The first effort to provide free computer access to legal information was made by two academics, Peter Martin and Tom Bruce, in 1992.<ref name="law.cornell.edu"/> Today, the [[Legal Information Institute]] freely publishes such resources as the text of the [[United States Constitution]], judgements of the [[United States Supreme Court]], and the text of the [[United States Code]].
The [[Australian Legal Information Institute]] (AusLII) was established soon after in 1995.<ref>"Electronic Law Journals – JILT 1997 (2) – AustLII's roles". University of Warwick. Retrieved 4 March 2010.</ref> Other legal information institutes, such as those of [[British and Irish Legal Information Institute|Great Britain and Ireland]] (BAILII), [[Canadian Legal Information Institute|Canada]] (CII) and South Africa (SAfLI) soon followed.<ref name="India 2015"/> LIIs were partially formalised in 2002 following the signing of the Declaration of Free Access to the Law, which has been signed by 54 countries.<ref>Sarah Glassmeyer and Pete Smith, 'Open Law: technology in service of the rule of law' (2014) Legal Information Management 181</ref> At the time of writing, the World Legal Information Institute contains in excess of 1800 databases from 123 jurisdictions.<ref>http://www.worldlii.org/ accessed: 16th June 2016</ref>
Many governments also publish legal information online. For example, UK legislation and statutory instruments have been publicly available online since 2010.<ref>http://www.legislation.gov.uk</ref> Depending on the jurisdiction in question, the decisions of higher appellate courts may also be published online, either by the Legal Information Institute or by the court service directly.<ref>See e.g. https://www.supremecourt.uk/decided-cases/</ref> Sources of [[European Union Law]] are published for free by [[EUR-Lex]] in 23 languages, including judgements of the European Courts.<ref>http://eur-lex.europa.eu/content/welcome/about.html</ref> Similarly, judgements of the [[European Court of Human Rights]] are published on its website.<ref>http://www.echr.coe.int/Pages/home.aspx?p=caselaw&c=#n14597620384884950241259_pointer</ref>

{{short description|A land mass now beneath the southern North Sea that connected Great Britain to continental Europe}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Doggerland.svg|thumb|right|250px|Map showing hypothetical extent of Doggerland (c. 10,000 BC), which provided a land bridge between Great Britain and continental Europe]]
'''Doggerland''' was an area of land, now submerged beneath the southern [[North Sea]], that connected [[Great Britain]] to [[continental Europe]]. It was flooded by rising sea levels around 6,500–6,200 BC. Geological surveys have suggested that it stretched from Britain's east coast to the [[Netherlands]] and the western coasts of Germany and the peninsula of [[Jutland]].<ref>[http://humanities.exeter.ac.uk/archaeology/research/projects/title,89282,en.html "The Doggerland Project", University of Exeter Department of Archaeology]</ref> It was probably a rich habitat with human habitation in the [[Mesolithic]] period,<ref name="usask">[http://geochemistry.usask.ca/bill/courses/Climate/Coastal%20catastrophe%20prt.pdf Patterson, W, "Coastal Catastrophe" (paleoclimate research document), University of Saskatchewan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409025923/http://geochemistry.usask.ca/bill/courses/Climate/Coastal%20catastrophe%20prt.pdf |date=9 April 2008 }}</ref> although rising sea levels gradually reduced it to low-lying islands before its final submergence, possibly following a [[tsunami]] caused by the [[Storegga Slide]].<ref name= bbc010514/>
The [[archaeology|archaeological]] potential of the area was first identified in the early 20th century, and interest intensified in 1931 when a [[commercial trawler|fishing trawler]] operating east of [[the Wash]] dragged up a barbed antler point that was subsequently dated to a time when the area was [[tundra]]. Vessels have dragged up remains of [[mammoth]], [[lion]] and other animals, as well as a few prehistoric tools and weapons.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.zmescience.com/science/geology/doggerland-europe-land/|title = Doggerland – the land that connected Europe and the UK 8000 years ago|date = February 5, 2015|accessdate = February 18, 2015|website = ZME Science|publisher = |last = Mihai|first = Andrei}}</ref>
Doggerland was named in the 1990s, after the [[Dogger Bank]], which in turn was named after the 17th century Dutch fishing boats called ''[[Dogger (boat)|doggers]]''.
==Formation== [[File:Doggerland3er_en.png|thumb|300px|left|Map showing hypothetical extent of Doggerland from [[Weichselian glaciation]] until the current situation]] Until the middle [[Pleistocene]], Britain was a peninsula of Europe, connected by the massive chalk [[Weald–Artois Anticline]] across the [[Straits of Dover]]. During the [[Anglian glaciation]], approximately 450,000 years ago, an ice sheet filled much of the [[North Sea]], with a large [[proglacial lake]] in the southern part fed by the [[Rhine]], [[Scheldt]] and [[Thames]] river systems. The catastrophic overflow of this lake carved a channel through the anticline, leading to the formation of the [[Channel River]], which carried the combined Scheldt and Thames to the Atlantic. This probably created the potential for Britain to become isolated from the continent during periods of high sea level, although some scientists argue that the final break did not occur until a second ice-dammed lake overflowed during the [[Marine isotope stage|MIS]]8 or MIS6 glaciations, around 340,000 or 240,000 years ago.<ref>{{cite book|title=The British Palaeolithic: Human Societies at the Edge of the Pleistocene World|first1=Paul|last1=Pettitt|first2=Mark|last2=White|publisher=Routledge|year=2012|pages=98–102, 277|location=Abingdon, UK|isbn=978-0-415-67455-3}}</ref>
During the most recent glaciation of the [[Last Glacial Maximum]], which ended around 18,000 years ago, the North Sea and much of the British Isles were covered with glacial ice and the sea level was about {{convert|120|m|ft|abbr=on}} lower. The climate later became warmer and during the [[Late Glacial Maximum]] around 12,000 BC Britain, as well as much of the North Sea and English Channel, was an expanse of low-lying [[tundra]].<ref name=sussex>[http://www.lifesci.sussex.ac.uk/teaching/C1119/mhe08%20lecture%206.pdf University of Sussex, School of Life Sciences] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609214154/http://www.lifesci.sussex.ac.uk/teaching/C1119/mhe08%20lecture%206.pdf |date=9 June 2011 }}, C1119 Modern human evolution, Lecture 6, slide 23</ref>
Evidence, including the contours of the present seabed, indicates that after the first main Ice Age, the [[Water divide|watershed]] between the North Sea and [[English Channel]] extended east from East Anglia then south-east to the [[Hook of Holland]], rather than across the Strait of Dover. The [[Seine]], [[Thames]], [[Meuse (river)|Meuse]], [[Scheldt]] and [[Rhine]] rivers joined and flowed west along the English Channel as a wide slow river before eventually reaching the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name="usask"/><ref name=sussex/> At about 10,000 BC the north-facing coastal area of Doggerland had a coastline of [[lagoon]]s, [[saltmarsh]]es, [[mudflat]]s and beaches as well as inland streams, rivers, [[marsh]]es and lakes. It may have been the richest hunting, fowling and fishing ground in Europe in the [[Mesolithic]] period.<ref name="usask"/><ref name=gaffney>[http://livebettermagazine.com/article/global-warming-and-lost-lands-understanding-the-effects-of-sea-level-rise/ Vincent Gaffney, "Global Warming and Lost Lands: Understanding the Effects of Sea Level Rise"]</ref>
One big river system found by 3D seismic survey, undertaken by the Birmingham "North Sea Palaeolandscapes Project," was the "Shotton River", which drained the south-east part of the [[Dogger Bank]] hill area into the east end of the [[Outer Silver Pit]] lake. It is named after Birmingham geologist [[Frederick William Shotton]].
==Disappearance== [[File:Doggerbank.jpg|thumb|upright|250px|The red line marks [[Dogger Bank]], which is most likely a [[moraine]] formed in the [[Pleistocene]].<ref name="Stride">{{Cite journal|last= Stride|first= A.H|date= January 1959|title= On the origin of the Dogger Bank, in the North Sea |journal= Geological Magazine |volume= 96|issue= 1|pages= 33–34|url= http://geolmag.geoscienceworld.org/cgi/content/abstract/96/1/33|accessdate= 12 January 2010|doi= 10.1017/S0016756800059197}}</ref>]] As ice melted at the end of [[Weichselian Ice Age|the last glacial period of the current ice age]], sea levels rose and the land began to tilt in an [[post-glacial rebound|isostatic adjustment]] as the huge weight of ice lessened. Doggerland eventually became submerged, cutting off what was previously the British peninsula from the European mainland by around 6500 BC.<ref name=sussex/><ref name="humanpast">{{cite book|last1=Scarre|first1=Chris|title=The Human Past: World Prehistory & the Development of Human Societies|date=2005|publisher=Thames & Hudson|location=London|isbn=978-0-500-28531-2|pages=180|ref=human past}}</ref> The Dogger Bank, an upland area of Doggerland, remained an island until at least 5000 BC.<ref name=sussex/><ref name=humanpast/> Key stages are now believed to have included the gradual evolution of a large tidal bay between eastern England and Dogger Bank by 9000 BC and a rapid sea-level rise thereafter, leading to Dogger Bank becoming an island and Great Britain becoming physically disconnected from the continent.<ref name=weninger>[http://www.personal.soton.ac.uk/ejr/Rohling-papers/2008-Weninger%20et%20al%20Documenta%20Praehistorica.pdf Bernhard Weninger et al., The catastrophic final flooding of Doggerland by the Storegga Slide tsunami, Documenta Praehistorica XXXV, 2008]</ref>
A recent hypothesis postulates that much of the remaining coastal land was flooded by a [[megatsunami]] around 6200 BC, caused by a submarine landslide off the coast of [[Norway]] known as the [[Storegga Slide]]. This suggests: "that the Storegga Slide tsunami would have had a catastrophic impact on the contemporary coastal Mesolithic population.... Britain finally became separated from the continent and in cultural terms, the Mesolithic there goes its own way."<ref name=weninger/> A study published in 2014 suggested that the only remaining parts of Doggerland at the time of the Storegga Slide were low-lying islands, but supported the view that the area had been abandoned at about the same time as the tsunamis.<ref name= bbc010514>{{cite web |last= Rincon |first= Paul |title= Prehistoric North Sea 'Atlantis' hit by 5m tsunami |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-27224243 |publisher= BBC News|date= 1 May 2014}}</ref>
Another view speculates that the Storegga tsunami devastated Doggerland but then ebbed back into the sea, and that later [[Lake Agassiz]] (in North America) burst releasing so much fresh water that sea levels over about two years rose to flood much of Doggerland and make Britain an island.<ref> ''Britain's Stone Age Tsunami'', [[Channel 4]], 8 to 9 pm, Thursday 30 May 2013 </ref>
==Discovery and investigation by archaeologists== [[File:200805231215 Wollhaarmammut Millie Schädel.jpeg|thumb|left|[[Woolly mammoth]] skull discovered by fishermen in the [[North Sea]], at Celtic and Prehistoric Museum, Ireland]] The prehistoric existence of what is now known as Doggerland was established in the late 19th century. [[H. G. Wells]] referred to the concept in his short story ''[[A Story of the Stone Age]]'' of 1897, set in "a time when one might have walked dryshod from France (as we call it now) to England, and when a broad and sluggish Thames flowed through its marshes to meet its father Rhine, flowing through a wide and level country that is under water in these latter days, and which we know by the name of the North Sea...Fifty thousand years ago it was, fifty thousand years if the reckoning of geologists is correct", though most of the action seems to occur in what is now [[Surrey]] and [[Kent]], but stretching out to Doggerland.<ref>[http://www.readbookonline.net/readOnLine/10821/ Online text]</ref>
The remains of plants brought to the surface from Dogger Bank were studied in 1913 by [[Paleobiology|paleobiologist]] [[Clement Reid]], and the remains of animals and worked flints from the [[Neolithic period]] had also been found.<ref name="Keith">{{Cite book| last=Keith|first=Arthur |title=The Antiquity of Man |publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt Ltd |date=15 August 2004|pages=41|chapter=3|isbn=81-7041-977-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nCxEDWs8kwgC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=submerged+forest+france#v=onepage&q=submerged%20forest%20france&f=false|accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref> In his book ''The Antiquity of Man'' of 1915, [[Anatomy|anatomist]] [[Sir Arthur Keith]] discussed the archaeological potential of the area.<ref name="Keith" /> In 1931, the [[Fishing trawler|trawler]] ''Colinda'' hauled up a lump of [[peat]] whilst fishing near the Ower Bank, {{convert|25|mi|order=flip}} east of [[Norfolk]]. The peat was found to contain a barbed antler point, possibly used as a [[harpoon]] or fish spear, {{convert|8.5|in|order=flip}} long, which dated from between 4,000 and 10,000 BC when the area was [[tundra]].<ref name="usask"/><ref name=gaffney/>
Interest was reinvigorated in the 1990s by [[Bryony Coles]], who named the area "Doggerland" ("after the great banks in the southern North Sea")<ref name=gaffney/> and produced speculative maps of the area.<ref name=gaffney/><ref name=coles>[http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=2023101 B.J. Coles. "Doggerland : a speculative survey (Doggerland : une prospection spéculative)", ''Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society''], {{ISSN|0079-497X}}, 1998, vol. 64, pp. 45–81 (3 p.1/4)</ref> Although she recognised that the current relief of the southern North Sea [[seabed]] is not a sound guide to the topography of Doggerland,<ref name=coles/> this topography has more recently begun to be reconstructed more authoritatively using [[Reflection seismology|seismic survey]] data obtained from oil exploration. Between 2003 and 2007 a team at the [[University of Birmingham]] led by [[Vincent Gaffney|Vince Gaffney]] and Ken Thomson mapped around {{convert|23,000|sqkm|sqmi|abbr=off}} of the Early Holocene landscape, using seismic data provided for research by [[Petroleum Geo-Services]], as part of the work of the University of Birmingham North Sea Palaeolandscapes Project.<ref>[http://www.iaalocal.bham.ac.uk/North_Sea_Palaeolandscapes/index.htm North Sea Palaeolandscapes Project]</ref> The results of this study were published as a technical monograph and a popular book on the history and archaeology of Doggerland.<ref name ="archaeology">[http://sci.tech-archive.net/Archive/sci.archaeology/2008-07/msg00136.html Laura Spinney, "The lost world: Doggerland"]</ref><ref name="GaffneyThomson2007">{{cite book|editor1=Vincent L. Gaffney|editor2=Kenneth Thomson|editor3=Simon Fitch|title=Mapping Doggerland: The Mesolithic Landscapes of the Southern North Sea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SrsrE8oZx44C&pg=PR11|year=2007|publisher=Archaeopress|isbn=978-1-905739-14-1|page=11}}</ref><ref>[http://www.britarch.ac.uk/books/Gaffney2009 Vincent Gaffney, Simon Fitch, David Smith, ''Europe's Lost World: The rediscovery of Doggerland'', University of Birmingham, 2009]</ref> Names have been given to some of its features: "The Spines" to a system of dunes above the broad "[[Frederick William Shotton|Shotton]] River", the upland area of the "Dogger Bank", a basin between two huge sandbanks called "The Outer Silver Pit"<ref name="Macfarlane2012">{{cite book|author=[[Robert Macfarlane (writer)|Robert Macfarlane]]|title=The Old Ways|year=2012|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-141-03058-6|page=70-71}}</ref>. [[File:Early Holocene landscape features mapped by the North Sea Palaeolandscapes Project.png|thumb|Early Holocene landscape features mapped by the North Sea Palaeolandscapes Project]]
A skull fragment of a [[Neanderthal]], dated at over 40,000 years old, was recovered from material dredged from the Middeldiep, some {{convert|10|mi|order=flip}} off the coast of [[Zeeland]], and exhibited in [[Leiden]] in 2009.<ref>[http://www.palarch.nl/2009/06/news-first-fossil-of-neanderthal-from-northsea-the-netherlands/ Palarch: Spectacular discovery of first-ever Dutch Neanderthal Fossil skull fragment unveiled by Minister Plasterk in National Museum of Antiquities], 15 June 2009</ref> In March 2010 it was reported that recognition of the potential archaeological importance of the area could affect the future development of offshore [[wind farms]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE62M12020100323 "Stone Age could complicate N. Sea wind farm plans", Reuters, 23 March 2010]</ref>
In July 2012, the results of study of Doggerland by the universities of [[University of Birmingham|Birmingham]], [[University of St Andrews|St Andrews]], [[University of Dundee|Dundee]], and [[University of Aberdeen|Aberdeen]], including surveys of artefacts, were displayed at the [[Royal Society]] summer exhibition in London.<ref name=bbc2012>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-18687504 BBC News, "Hidden Doggerland underworld uncovered in North Sea", 3 July 2012]. Accessed 4 July 2012</ref> Richard Bates of St Andrews University said:<ref name=bbc2012/>
{{Quote|We have speculated for years on the lost land's existence from bones dredged by fishermen all over the North Sea, but it's only since working with oil companies in the last few years that we have been able to re-create what this lost land looked like.... We have now been able to model its flora and fauna, build up a picture of the ancient people that lived there and begin to understand some of the dramatic events that subsequently changed the land, including the sea rising and a devastating tsunami.}}
Since 2015, the [[University of Bradford]]'s [https://lostfrontiers.teamapp.com/ Europe's Lost Frontiers] project has continued mapping the prehistoric landscapes of Doggerland and has used this data to direct a programme of extensive coring of marine palaeochannels. Sediment from the cores has provided sedimentary DNA as well as conventional environmental data and these will be used in a major computational modelling programme replicating colonisation of the submerged landscape.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://lostfrontiers.teamapp.com/|title=Lost Frontiers (Lost Frontiers) Home page - Lost Frontiers An Erc Research Project team/club based in University of Bradford, United Kingdom. {{!}} Team App|last=App|first=Team|website=Lost Frontiers|access-date=2017-05-08}}</ref><ref name=sarah>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/environment/archaeology/11836627/British-Atlantis-archaeologists-begin-exploring-lost-world-of-Doggerland.html |title=British Atlantis: archaeologists begin exploring lost world of Doggerland|author= Sarah Knapton|work=Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=1 September 2015 |accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref>
==In popular culture== * The "Mammoth Journey" episode of the BBC television programme ''[[Walking with Beasts]]'' is partly set on the dry bed of the southern North Sea. * The area featured in a 2007 episode of the Channel 4 ''[[Time Team (specials)]]'' documentary series called "Britain's Drowned World".<ref>[https://heritageaction.wordpress.com/2011/01/26/britains-drowned-world-a-time-team-special Heritage Action]</ref> * The first chapter of [[Edward Rutherfurd]]'s novel ''[[Sarum (novel)|Sarum]]'' describes the flooding of Doggerland. * [[Science fiction]] author [[Stephen Baxter (author)|Stephen Baxter]]'s ''Northland'' trilogy is set in an alternative timeline in which Doggerland (Northland in the books) is never inundated. * The opening song of [[Ian Anderson]]'s 2014 album, ''[[Homo Erraticus]]'', is titled "Doggerland," and provides a first person narrative from the point of view of the prehistoric people who might have lived there.

[[Image:Dora Maria Tellez 01.jpg|thumb|Dora María Téllez c. 1980 Sandinista Cmdr.]] '''Dora María Téllez''' (born 1955) is a [[Nicaragua]]n historian who is well known for her involvement in the [[Sandinista]] Revolution, which deposed the [[Somoza]] regime in 1979. As a young university medical student in Leon in the 1970s, Téllez was recruited by the [[FSLN]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/32396348|title=Sandino's daughters : testimonies of Nicaraguan women in struggle|last=1936-|first=Randall, Margaret,|date=1995|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=0813522145|edition=Rev.|location=New Brunswick, NJ|oclc=32396348}}</ref> The FSLN, also referred to as The Sandinista National Liberation Front, was a socialist party in Nicaragua.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/50174899|title=The many faces of Sandinista democracy|last=Katherine.|first=Hoyt,|date=1997|publisher=Ohio University Center for International Studies|isbn=0896801977|location=Athens|oclc=50174899}}</ref> The early work of Téllez within the FSLN was through student movements centered around support work for members active in the mountains.<ref name=":0" /> Téllez went on to become a comandante in the popular revolt to oust the Nicaraguan dictator, [[Anastasio Somoza Debayle]].<ref name=":0" />
As "Commander Two", at age 22, she was third in command in an [[:es:Operación Chanchera|operation]] on August 22, 1978 that occupied the Nicaraguan National Palace in Managua, where the Nicaraguan National Assembly was in full session.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2006-11-30|title=Tellez, Dora Maria (1957–)|url=http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/CX2588823052/GVRL?u=umuser&sid=GVRL&xid=d72738cc|journal=Dictionary of Women Worldwide: 25,000 Women Through the Ages|language=English|volume=2}}</ref> They captured 1,500 civilian hostages and threatened their lives unless their demands were met.<ref name=":5" /> The demands included a prisoner release and a monetary ransom. There was a subsequent release of key [[Sandinista]] political prisoners and a million dollars ransom payment. Téllez played a role in managing these negotiations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Still Fighting|last=Isbester|first=Katherine|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|year=2001|location=|pages=}}</ref>
This event had repercussions for the 50-year-old Somoza dynasty by revealing the potential vulnerability of the Somoza regime. It also helped the [[Sandinista National Liberation Front|FSLN]] win support from Latin American governments, unite diverse factions of the opposition to the regime, and prompt them into action.<ref name=":5" /> Following the operation, thousands of youths and women joined the Sandinista movement.<ref name=":0" /> A popular insurrection grew along with the FSLN and contributed to the fall of the Somoza regime on July 19, 1979.<ref name=":0" />
==Military commander during the Nicaraguan Civil War== Upon her arrival in Panama with the released Sandinistas in August 1978, Téllez trained in Cuba and Panama to become a military commander. In February 1979 she was back fighting in Nicaragua and she went on to establish a place in the Tercerista leadership structure. For five months she led [[Sandinista]] platoons throughout the country in skirmishes with the [[Nicaraguan National Guard]]: first in the Southern Front with [[Edén Pastora]]'s forces, and later in Central and northern Nicaragua. According to [[Sandinista]] Commander Mónica Baltodano, her raids on the northern provinces in conjunction with Cmdr.
Finally, she led the Sandinista units fighting the enemy's elite forces block by block for six consecutive weeks until capturing in June 1979 the city of [[León, Nicaragua|León]], the first major city to fall to the Sandinistas in the Revolution, followed by Managua two weeks later.<ref name=":3" /> This was followed by the Sandinista Provisional Government Junta's installation in this city soon after.<ref name=":3" />
==Public service in the Sandinista Movement== An increase in government repression and rise of political prisoners being taken prompted Téllez to go underground in 1976.<ref name=":0" /> While underground she did educational work in the mountains.<ref name=":0" /> She later served as Minister of Health in the first Sandinista administration.<ref name=":2" /> The administration's public health campaign that won Nicaragua the UN Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization's prize for exceptional health progress.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/51504445|title=After the Revolution : gender and democracy in El Salvador, Nicaragua, and Guatemala|last=A.|first=Luciak, Ilja|date=2001|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|isbn=0801876419|location=Baltimore|oclc=51504445}}</ref> Specifically, Téllez has been quoted discussing the specific health inequalities present in the mining industry in Nicaragua.<ref name=":5" />
Within the Sandinistas government, Téllez held positions alongside religious figures to advocate for gay and lesbian rights, as well as reproductive rights for women in Nicaragua.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1004570034|title=Status Envy : The Politics of Catholic Higher Education|others=Hendershott, Anne|isbn=1351488163|edition=1st|oclc=1004570034}}</ref>
==Academic life as a historian== Téllez wrote publications on Nicaraguan history that underscores the importance of the north-central region of the country to the nation's political and economic history. In 2004 she was appointed Robert F. Kennedy Visiting Professor in Latin American studies at the [[Harvard Divinity School]], but was barred from obtaining an entry visa to the [[United States|US]] on grounds that she was a terrorist, citing as evidence the raid on the Nicaraguan National Palace in Managua via the Patriot Act. <ref>{{Citation | title = US bars Nicaragua heroine as 'terrorist' | url=https://www.theguardian.com/usa/story/0,12271,1430305,00.html | last = Campbell | first = Duncan | accessdate = 2007-02-16 | date=March 4, 2005 | publisher = [[Guardian Unlimited]] | work=The Guardian | location=London}} </ref><ref>{{Citation | first = William L. | last = Jusino | title = Would-Be Prof Denied Entry Visa | url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=506299 | publisher = [[The Harvard Crimson]] | accessdate = 2007-02-16}}</ref> This prompted 122 members of the academic community from [[Harvard University|Harvard]] and 15 other North American universities to publish a statement in her defense, stating:
{{quote| The accusation made by the State Department against Dora María Téllez... amounts to political persecution of those who have engaged in overthrowing the atrocious dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza in Nicaragua...This regime was almost universally viewed as criminal and inhumane, and yet it was financially and militarily supported by the United States...In reference to dictatorships, just as the State Department cannot affirm that the activities of Nelson Mandela against the atrocious dictatorship of apartheid in South Africa were terrorist activities, neither can it affirm that Dora María's activities against the atrocious Somoza dictatorship were terrorist.<ref>{{Citation|first=Tim |last=Rogers |title=Schooled in Revolution |url=http://zmagsite.zmag.org/Oct2005/rogers1005.html |format=– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3ARogers+intitle%3ASchooled+in+Revolution&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |accessdate=2007-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206143403/http://zmagsite.zmag.org/Oct2005/rogers1005.html |archivedate=February 6, 2007 }}</ref>}}
==Political career== Early experience within the FSLN political party included Téllez's position as the Political Secretary for Managua.<ref name=":2" /> Téllez also served as a member of the Council of the State.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/28021881|title=Sandino's daughters revisited : feminism in Nicaragua|last=1936-|first=Randall, Margaret,|date=1994|publisher=Rutgers University Press|isbn=0813520258|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|oclc=28021881}}</ref> The first congress of the FSLN had an election in 1990 which prompted discontent regarding the election process however the Directorate decided that the subsequent election of a new body would be done so by slate rather than voting for individual members.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Democracy and Socialism in Sandinista Nicaragua|last=Vanden|first=Harry E.|last2=Prevost|first2=Gary|publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers|year=1993|location=Boulder, CO|pages=}}</ref> This stunted the potential political candidacy of Téllez, which was being pushed by many rank-and-file members.<ref name=":1" /> Téllez would have been the Directorate's first female member.<ref name=":1" />
In 1995 Téllez founded the [[Sandinista Renovation Movement]] (MRS) after resigning her seat in the [[FSLN]].<ref name=":2" /> Other former [[Sandinistas]] such as [[Ernesto Cardenal]] and [[Sergio Ramírez]] have joined the MRS political party.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/70763707|title=The Undermining of the Sandinista Revolution|date=1999|publisher=Macmillan|others=Prevost, Gary., Vanden, Harry E.|isbn=1349275115|location=Basingstoke|oclc=70763707}}</ref> The MRS political party opposed the current corruption in the Nicaraguan government and appointed Herty Lewites to run as the party's candidate in the 2006 presidential election against Daniel Ortega.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/858357241|title=From Nicaragua Principles for Life and Mission.|date=2013|publisher=West Bow Pr|others=Cox, Bill.|isbn=149080482X|oclc=858357241}}</ref> Four months before the election was to be held, Lewites died of natural causes.<ref name=":4" /> Daniel Ortega, whom was president from 1985 to 1990, won the presidential election and regained political power in Nicaragua.<ref name=":4" />
On June 4, 2008, Téllez began a hunger strike to protest the "dictatorship of Daniel Ortega", her former comrade-in-arms who was elected again to the presidency in November, 2006.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/657770161|title=Unfinished revolution Daniel Ortega and Nicaragua's struggle for liberation|last=1955-|first=Morris, Kenneth Earl,|date=2010|publisher=Lawrence Hill Books|isbn=1569767564|location=Chicago|oclc=657770161}}</ref> Ortega and his supporters stripped the MRS of its legal status about one week later. Téllez suspended her hunger strike on June 16, after doctors told her she would suffer irreparable damage if she continued her fast. She vowed to begin "a new stage of struggle" against what she termed the dictatorial policies of Daniel Ortega.
== The Global Feminisms Project == Dora María Téllez is one of many women part of The [[Global Feminisms Project]], an archive of interviews from women activists and scholars from 7 different countries.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://globalfeminisms.umich.edu/about|title=About the Global Feminisms Project {{!}} Global Feminisms at the University of Michigan|website=globalfeminisms.umich.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-31}}</ref> This archive was created in 2002 at the [[University of Michigan]].<ref name=":6" /> The oral history of Téllez and many other Nicaraguan women, as well as women the USA, China, India, Poland, USA, Brazil, and Russia are recorded by The Global Feminisms Project.<ref name=":6" />

{{Other uses|Doublet (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=February 2016}} In [[etymology]], two or more words in the same language are called '''doublets''' or '''etymological twins''' or '''twinlings''' (or possibly triplets, and so forth) when they have different phonological forms but the same etymological root. Often, but not always, the words entered the language through different routes. Given that the kinship between words that have the same root and the same meaning is fairly obvious, the term is mostly used to characterize pairs of words that have diverged at least somewhat in meaning.{{cite book |chapterurl=//archive.org/stream/principlesofengl01skeauoft#page/414/mode/2up|first=Walter William|last=Skeat|authorlink=Walter William Skeat|title=Principles of English Etymology: The Native Element|chapter=Doublets and Compounds|page=414''ff'', §389–391 and ''passim'' in all volumes}} For example, [[English language|English]] ''pyre'' and ''fire'' are doublets with only remotely connected meanings despite both descending ultimately from the same [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]] (PIE) word *''{{PIE|péh₂ur}}''. Words with similar meanings but subtle differences contribute to the richness of modern English, and many of these are doublets. A good example consists of the doublets ''frail'' and ''fragile''. (These are both ultimately from the [[Latin]] adjective ''{{lang|la|fragilis}}'', but ''frail'' evolved naturally through its slowly changing forms in Old French and Middle English, whereas ''fragile'' is a learned borrowing directly from Latin in the 15th century.)All English dictionaries list "easily broken, fragile" as one meaning of ''frail'', but a ''frail tea cup'' would indicate the speaker considers it more easily broken than a ''fragile tea cup''. In other words, ''fragile'' is the more usual term used to describe cups and other goods that break as easily as expected, and this is what is written on stickers applied to luggage, for example. When talking about people, both terms can also be used, but ''frail'' is the more usual term, so ''frail old woman'' is a common expression, whereas ''fragile old woman'' adds a nuance implying an infirmity that is not merely physical. Another example of nearly synonymous doublets is ''aperture'' and ''overture'' (the commonality behind the meanings is "opening"). But doublets may develop divergent meanings, such as the ''opposite'' words ''host'' and ''guest'', which come from the same PIE word *''{{PIE|gʰóstis}}'' and already existed as a doublet in Latin ''{{linktext|hospes|lang=la}}'' and then [[Old French]],''{{linktext|oste|lang=fro}}'' or ''{{lang|fro|[[wikt:hoste#Old French|hoste]]}}'' in Old French. {{Cite OED2|host, n.2}} before being borrowed into English. Doublets also vary with respect to how far their forms have diverged. For example, the connection between ''[[wikt:Special:Search/levy|levy]]'' and ''[[levee]]'' is easy to guess, whereas the connection between ''sovereign'' and ''soprano'', or ''{{linktext|grammar}}'' and ''{{linktext|glamour}}'', is harder to guess. ==Origin== Doublets can develop in various ways, according to which route the two forms took from the origin to their current form. Complex, multi-step paths are possible, though in many cases groups of terms follow the same path. Simple paths are discussed below, with the simplest distinction being that doublets in a given language can have their root in the same language (or an ancestor), or may originate in a separate language. ===Native origin=== Most simply, a native word can at some point split into two distinct forms, staying within a single language, as with English ''too'' which split from ''to''.http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=too Alternatively, a word may be inherited from a parent language, and a [[cognate]] borrowed from a separate sister language. In other words, one route was direct inheritance, while the other route was inheritance followed by borrowing. In English this means one word inherited from a Germanic source, with, e.g., a Latinate cognate term borrowed from Latin or a Romance language. In English this is most common with words which can be traced back to [[Indo-European languages]], which in many cases share the same [[Proto-Indo-European language|proto-Indo-European]] root, such as [[Romance language|Romance]] ''[[beef]]'' and [[Germanic language|Germanic]] ''[[cow]]''. However, in some cases the branching is more recent, dating only to proto-Germanic, not to PIE; many words of Germanic origin occur in French and other Latinate languages, and hence in some cases were both inherited by English (from proto-Germanic) and borrowed from French or another source – see [[List of English Latinates of Germanic origin]]. The forward linguistic path also reflects cultural and historical transactions; often the name of an animal comes from Germanic while the name of its cooked meat comes from Romance. Since English is unusual in that it borrowed heavily from two distinct branches of the same language [[family tree]] – Germanic and Latinate/Romance – it has a relatively high number of this latter type of etymological twin. See [[list of Germanic and Latinate equivalents in English]] for further examples and discussion. Less commonly, a native word may be borrowed into a foreign language, then [[reborrowed]] back into the original language, existing alongside the original term. An English example is ''[[animation]]'' and ''[[anime]]'' "Japanese animation", which was reborrowed from Japanese {{lang|ja|アニメ}} ''{{lang|ja-Latn|anime}}''. Such a word is sometimes called a ''{{lang|de|Rückwanderer}}'' (German for "one who wanders back").{{cite web |title=Etymology: φλιτζάνι, fincan, فنجان |url=http://hoapp.com/thread-81754-1-1.html |website=Discuz! |accessdate=6 November 2014 |date=2011-06-20 |quote=a wild guess — the Persian word pingân seems to suggest the form 'finjan' is a reloan from Arabic. If there is a Pers. word ‘finjan”, this rather seems to suggest a Rückwanderer from Turkish – not from Arabic. |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141106161903/http://hoapp.com/thread-81754-1-1.html |archivedate=6 November 2014 }} ===Borrowed origin=== In case of twins of foreign origin, which consist of two borrowings (of related terms), one can distinguish if the borrowing is of a term and a descendent, or of two cognate terms (siblings). Etymological twins are often a result of chronologically separate borrowing from a source language. In the case of English, this usually means once from French during the [[Norman conquest of England|Norman invasion]], and again later, after the word had evolved separately in French. An example of this is ''warranty'' and ''guarantee''. Another possibility is borrowing from both a language and its daughter language. In English this is usually Latin and some other Romance language, particularly French – see [[Latin influence in English]]. The distinction between this and the previous is whether the source language has changed to a different language or not. Less directly, a term may be borrowed both directly from a source language and indirectly via an intermediate language. In English this is most common in borrowings from Latin, and borrowings from French that are themselves from Latin; less commonly from Greek directly and through Latin. In case of borrowing cognate terms, rather than descendents, most simply an existing doublet can be borrowed: two contemporary twin terms can be borrowed. More remotely, cognate terms from different languages can be borrowed, such as ''[[sauce]]'' (Old French) and ''[[salsa (sauce)|salsa]]'' (Spanish), both ultimately from Latin, or ''[[tea]]'' (Dutch ''{{lang|nl|thee}}'') and ''chai'' (Hindi), both ultimately from [[Chinese languages|Chinese]]. This last pair reflects the history of how tea has entered English via different trade routes. ==By language== ===English=== Many thousands of English examples can be found, grouped according to their earliest deducible Indo-European ancestor.Calvert Watkins, ''The American Heritage Dictionary of Indo-European Roots''. In some cases over a hundred English words can be traced to a single root. Some random examples in English include: *''[[hospitality|host]]'' and ''[[wikt:Special:Search/guest|guest]]'', the former through Latin and the latter through Germanic *''strange'' and ''extraneous'' (from Latin, the former via Old French) *''[[word]]'' and ''[[verb]]'', the former through Germanic and the latter through Latin *''[[shadow]], [[shade (shadow)|shade]]'' and ''[[shed]]'' (all three from [[Old English]] ''{{lang|ang|sceadu}}'' "shadow, shade") *''stand, stay, state, status'' and ''static'' (native, Middle French, Latin (twice) and Ancient Greek via Latin, from the same Indo-European root) * ''[[wikt:chief|chief]]'', ''[[chef]]'', ''[[cape (geography)|cape]]'', ''[[capo]]'', ''[[caput]]'' and ''[[head]]'' (French (twice), Latin via French, Italian, Latin, and Germanic, all from the same Indo-European word *''{{PIE|ka(u)put}}'' "head") *''secure'' and ''sure'' (from Latin, the latter via French) *''[[capital (economics)|capital]]'', ''[[cattle]]'' and ''[[personal property|chattel]]'' (from Latin, Norman French and standard French) *''plant'' and ''clan'' (from Latin, the latter via [[Old Irish]]) *''right, rich, raj, rex, regalia, reign, royal'' and ''[[Brazilian real|real]]'' (from Germanic, Celtic, Sanskrit, Latin (twice), French (twice) and Portuguese cognates, respectively) *''[[carton]]'' and ''[[cartoon]]'', both ultimately Italian ''{{lang|it|cartone}}'' *''ward'' and ''guard'' (from Norman, the latter via French, both from Germanic); also ''warden'' and ''guardian''. *''[[chrism]], [[cream]]'' and ''[[dirt|grime]]'' (the first from Greek, the second from French, in the 14th and 19th centuries, respectively, the last from Germanic) *''[[cow]]'' and ''[[beef]]'' (from Proto-Indo-European; the former through Germanic – i.e. natively via Old English – the latter through Latin via French) *''[[wheel]]'', ''[[wikt:cycle|cycle]]'' and ''[[chakra]]'' (Germanic, Greek via Latin and Sanskrit, all from Proto-Indo-European *''{{PIE|kʷékʷlo-}}'' "wheel") *''frenetic'' and ''frantic'' (both from Greek, via Old French and Latin). More English doublets from Greek in [[English words of Greek origin]] *''[[cave]]'' and ''cavern'' (from Latin ''{{lang|la|cavus}}'', via French and Germanic languages respectively) *''price, prize, praise, pry'' (a lever) and ''[[price|prix]]'' (all from French, some diverged in English) *''corn, kernel'' and ''grain'' (all ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *''{{PIE|grnóm}}'', the first two natively via Proto-Germanic (g → k), the last via Latin, borrowed from Old French) *''clock, cloche, cloak'' and ''glockenspiel'' (from Medieval Latin ''{{lang|la|clocca}}'' "bell", via Middle Dutch, French (twice) and German respectively.) *''pique, pike'' (weapon) – both from Middle French ''{{lang|frm|pique}}'' *''[[mr|mister]], [[master (form of address)|master]], [[meister]], [[maestro]], [[mistral (wind)|mistral]]'' (a Mediterranean wind), ''[[magistrate]]'' are all ultimately derived from Latin ''{{lang|la|magister}}'' ("teacher"). *''[[wikt:equip|equip]], [[ship]], [[skiff]]'' and ''[[skipper (boating)|skipper]]'' (Old French, Old English, Old Italian via Middle French, and Middle Dutch, respectively, all from Proto-Germanic ''{{lang|gem-x-proto|skipą}}'' "ship") *''[[wikt:domain|domain]]'', ''[[demesne]]'', ''[[dominion]]'' and ''[[dungeon]]'' (all from French) *''[[Slav]]'' and ''[[slave]]'' (from Latin and French, respectively, both ultimately from Proto-Slavic via Greek) *''Discrete'' and ''Discreet'' (from Latin, diverged in English, now [[homophones]]) *''[[wikt:Charity|charity]], [[cheer]], [[wikt:cherish|cherish]]'' and ''[[whore]]'' (French (thrice), the second via Anglo-Norman, and Germanic, respectively, all ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *''{{PIE|kāro-}}'', *''{{PIE|kéh₂ro-}}'' "dear; loved") ====Norman vs. standard or Modern French==== Many words of [[French language|French]] origin were borrowed twice or more. There were at least three periods of borrowing: One that occurred shortly after the [[Norman Conquest]] and came from [[Norman French]], one in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries from standard (Parisian) French at the time when English nobles were switching from French to English, and a third one during the sixteenth to nineteenth century, when France was at the height of its power and international influence. Examples of doublets from the first and second periods are ''catch'' vs. ''chase'', ''cattle'' vs. ''chattel'', and ''warden'' vs. ''guardian''. More recent borrowings are often distinguished by maintaining the French spelling and pronunciation, e.g. ''chef'' (vs. ''chief''), ''pâté'' (vs. ''paste''), ''fête'' (vs. ''feast''). There are multiple doublets caused by the ''w'' → ''g'' and ''ca'' → ''cha'' sound changes, which happened in standard French but not Norman French. Several of these examples also reflect changes that occurred after Old French which caused the possible environments of {{ipa|[s]}} to be greatly reduced. {| class="wikitable sortable" !colspan=2| English words from French |- !from Norman French !from standard Old or Modern French |- |car||chariot |- |castle||chateau |- |catch||chase |- |cattle||chattel |- |convey||convoy |- |paste||pâté |- |feast||fête |- |hostel||hotel |- |pocket||pouch |- |reward||regard |- |wallop||gallop |- |warden||guardian |- |wardrobe||garderobe |- |warranty||guarantee |- |wile, wily||guile |} ===Chinese=== {{Main|Chinese character classification#Derivative cognates|Literary and colloquial readings of Chinese characters}} Derivative cognates are a [[Chinese character classification|classification of Chinese characters]] which have similar meanings and often the same etymological root, but which have diverged in pronunciation and meaning. An example is the doublet {{lang|zh|考}} and {{lang|zh|老}}. At one time they were pronounced similarly and meant "old (person)." {{lang|zh|老}} ({{IPA|/lɑʊ̯˨˩˦/}} in [[Standard Mandarin]]) has retained this meaning, but {{lang|zh|考}} {{IPA|/kʰɑʊ̯˨˩˦/}} now mainly means "examine". Differing [[Literary and colloquial readings of Chinese characters|literary and colloquial readings]] of certain [[Chinese character]]s are common doublets in many [[varieties of Chinese|Chinese varieties]], and the reading distinctions for certain phonetic features often typify a dialect group. For a given Chinese [[variety (linguistics)|variety]], colloquial readings typically reflect native vernacular phonology. Literary readings are used in some formal settings ([[recitation]], some loanwords and names) and originate from other, typically more [[prestige (sociolinguistics)|prestigious]] varieties. Sometimes literary and colloquial readings of the same character have different meanings. For example, in [[Cantonese]], the character {{lang|zh|平}} can have the colloquial pronunciation {{IPA|/pʰɛŋ˨˩/}} ("inexpensive"), and the literary pronunciation {{IPA|/pʰɪŋ˨˩/}} ("flat"). ===Japanese=== In [[Japanese language|Japanese]], doublets are most significant in borrowings from Chinese, and are visible as different [[on'yomi]] (Sino-Japanese readings) of [[kanji]] characters. There have been three major periods of borrowing from Chinese, together with some modern borrowings. These borrowings are from different regions (hence different Chinese varieties) and different periods, and thus the pronunciations have varied, sometimes widely. However, due to consistent Chinese writing, with cognate [[morpheme]]s represented by the same character, the etymological relation is clear. This is most significant at the level of morphemes, where a given character is pronounced differently in different words, but in some cases the same word was borrowed twice. In scholarly terms, these have been very valuable for reconstructing the sounds of [[Middle Chinese]], and understanding how the pronunciations differed between Chinese regions and varied over time. ===New Indo-Aryan=== In [[Hindi language|Hindi]] and other [[New Indo-Aryan]] languages, native doublets are identified as either ''{{lang|sa-Latn|[[tadbhava]]}}'' ('became that'), which is ultimately derived from [[Sanskrit]] but underwent changes through time, or ''{{lang|sa-Latn|[[tatsama]]}}'' ('same as that'), which is borrowed directly from literary Sanskrit. For example, Hindi ''{{lang|sa-Latn|[[wikt:बाघ|bāgh]]}}'' 'tiger' is derived by historical stages ({{lang|sa-Latn|tadbhava}}) from Sanskrit ''{{lang|sa-Latn|[[wikt:व्याघ्र|vyāghra]]}}'' 'tiger'. Meanwhile, Hindi has also directly borrowed ({{lang|sa-Latn|tatsama}}) the Sanskrit word ''{{lang|sa-Latn|vyāghra}}'', meaning 'tiger' in a more literary register. ===Polish=== ;Doublets * ''{{lang|pl|(o-) pierdolić}}'' ("to fuck, babble, condemn," vulgar language), ''{{lang|pl|(o-) pierdzielić}}'' ("babble, condemn," informal language)—cognate to Russian {{lang|ru|определять}} ("determine") ;Triplets * ''{{lang|pl|[[:pl:upiór|upiór]]}}'', ''{{lang|pl|[[:pl:wąpierz|wąpierz]]}}'', ''{{lang|pl|[[:pl:wampir|wampir]]}}'' ("[[vampire]]"; see the [[:pl:Wampir#Etymologia|etymology of ''{{lang|pl|wampir|nocat=y}}'']]) * ''{{lang|pl|szczać}}'' ("piss", vulgar), ''{{lang|pl|sikać}}'' ("spout", plain, informal), ''{{lang|pl|siusiać}}'' ("pee," childish, euphemism; the latter is possibly an irregular diminutive derivation of the former) * ''{{lang|pl|[[:pl:magister|magister]]}}'', ''{{lang|pl|[[:pl:majster|majster]]}}'', ''{{lang|pl|[[:pl:mistrz|mistrz]]}}'': from German ''{{lang|de|Meister}}'', Dutch ''{{lang|nl|meester}}'', and Latin ''{{lang|la|magister}}''; cognate to Italian ''{{lang|it|maestro}}'', English ''master, mister'' ===Spanish=== As with many languages in Europe, a great deal of borrowing from written Latin – ''{{lang|es|latinismos}}'' ([[Latinism]]s), or ''{{lang|es|cultismos}}'' (learnèd words) – occurred during the Renaissance and the early modern era. Because Spanish is itself a [[Romance language]] already with many native words of Latin ancestry (transmitted orally, so with natural sound changes),{{cite book |last=Dworkin |first=Steven N. |title=A History of the Spanish Lexicon |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V4f8ZpJAhgIC&pg=PA158 |year=2012 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-954114-0 |page=158 }} the later written borrowing created a number of doublets. Adding to this was Spain's conquest by the Moors in the Middle Ages, leading to another vector for creating doublets (Latin to Arabic to Spanish). {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !(oral) !''{{lang|es|latinismo}}'' !via Arabic !original Latin |- | {{lang|es|bicha}}
("bug") || {{lang|es|bestia}}
("beast")|||| {{lang|la|bestia}} |- | {{lang|es|llave}}

("denarius coin")|||| {{lang|la|denarius}} |} ==See also== * [[Reborrowing]] * [[Cognate]], specifically, those within the same language * [[False friend]]s that may develop in the same way ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite book |author=Walter William Skeat |title=A Concise Etymological Dictionary of the English Language |chapter=List of Doublets |page=599''ff'' |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8X0ZAAAAYAAJ |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8X0ZAAAAYAAJ&q=list+of+doublets#v=page }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Doublet (Linguistics)}} [[Category:Historical linguistics]] [[Category:Types of words]]

'''Easyswap''' is a [[Switzerland]]-based on-line [[local exchange trading system]] (LETS) platform featuring [[Geolocation|geolocation data]] as well as a [[complementary currency]].
== History ==
Easyswap began as an initiative of the city of [[Lausanne]], Switzerland, to reduce social problems such as long-term unemployment and [[social exclusion]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Editorial|title=Les biens et les compétences s’échangent sur Easyswap|url=http://archives.24heures.ch/VQ/LAUSANNE/-/article-2008-10-2248/editorial|accessdate=21 November 2011|newspaper=24 Heures|date=October 29, 2008}}</ref>
A working group, made up of welfare recipients recruited by the city's social services department, came up with the idea of a web-based project modeled on [[local exchange trading systems]] (LETS).<ref>{{cite news|last=Pilet|first=François|title=L'échange de services perce sur le Net|url=https://www.easyswap.org/images/cms/medias/Le_Temps_30_10_2008.png|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=Le Temps|date=October 30, 2008}}</ref> Their project was to serve two purposes: promote [[social inclusion]] by nurturing contacts between different societal groups and encourage the [[sustainable consumption]] of consumer goods.<ref>{{cite news|last=Meyer|first=Guillaume|title=A Lausanne, une monnaie internet signe le retour de l'économie de troc|url=https://www.easyswap.org/images/cms/medias/Agefi_30_10_2008.png|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=Agefi (Switzerland)|date=October 30, 2008}}</ref>
Administered by an eponymous non profit association, easyswap.org was officially launched in October, 2008.<ref>{{cite news|last=Monnier|first=Philippe D.|title=Le troc remis au goût du jour|url=http://www.pme.ch/de/artikelanzeige/artikelanzeige.asp?pkBerichtNr=177504|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=PME Magazine|date=February 27, 2009}}</ref>
In August 2011, a version of the easyswap platform was developed for the [[University of Lausanne]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Despont|first=Aurélie|title=Prêt à partager?|url=http://www.unil.ch/webdav/site/unicom/shared/uniscope/2011-2012/566.pdf|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=Uniscope|date=September 12 – October 9, 2011}}</ref>
== The Swap ==
The swap is a virtual, [[complementary currency]] in use on the easyswap platform. The swap has a "theoretical value" of one [[Swiss franc]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Pilet|first=François|title=L'échange de services perce sur le Net|url=https://www.easyswap.org/images/cms/medias/Le_Temps_30_10_2008.png|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=Le Temps|date=October 30, 2008}}</ref> and cannot be bought or sold using any other currency.<ref>{{cite news|last=Meyer|first=Guillaume|title=A Lausanne, une monnaie internet signe le retour de l'économie de troc|url=https://www.easyswap.org/images/cms/medias/Agefi_30_10_2008.png|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=Agefi (Switzerland)|date=October 30, 2008}}</ref> Its [[value (economics)|value]] is determined by individual members who are free to set their own prices.<ref>{{cite news|last=Crivelli|first=Marie-Antoinette|title=Comment s'enrichir sans jamais toucher un seul franc!|url=http://archives.lematin.ch/loisirs/multimedia/comment-senrichir-sans-jamais-toucher-un-seul-franc-2008-11-02|accessdate=17 January 2012|newspaper=Le Matin|date=November 2, 2008}}</ref>
== Swap 'n' roll ==
The easyswap platform uses an [[open source]] technology based on [[PHP5]] [[Zend Framework]] developed and maintained by Swap 'n' roll.
Other open source LETS platforms include [[Cyclos]], [http://weblets.sourceforge.net/ WebLETS] and [http://www.hughbarnard.org/?q=node/3 Cclite].

'''Elizabeth Valerie Hume''' (born 29 October 1956) is a Canadian phonologist. Hume received her Ph.D. from [[Cornell University]] in 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://linguistics.cornell.edu/alumni|title=Alumni {{!}} Linguistics Cornell Arts & Sciences|website=linguistics.cornell.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> She was a Professor of Linguistics at the [[Ohio State University]] from 1992 to 2011. From 2006-2011, she served as professor and chair of the Department of Linguistics. From 2011-2017, she was a Professor of Linguistics at [[University of Canterbury]] in New Zealand. She returned to Ohio State to serve as Vice Provost and Dean of Undergraduate Education on October 1, 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oaa.osu.edu/hume-beth|title=Hume, Beth {{!}} Office of Academic Affairs, The Ohio State University|website=oaa.osu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>
She is an associate editor of [[Phonology (journal)|Phonology]] from 2008 to the present.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/phonology/information/editorial-board|title=Editorial board|website=Cambridge Core|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>
Her fields of research are sound systems of human language, factors influencing language variation and change, and the role of information and predictability in shaping language systems.<ref>{{cite news|title=Elizabeth V. Hume (CV)|url=http://www.canterbury.ac.nz/spark/UCResearchProfileResources/Researcher/4536187/Hume_CV_07-2016.pdf|accessdate=12 November 2016|publisher=University of Canterbury|date=15 July 2016}}</ref>
